questions.question_text: How do employers protect assets with security policies pertaining to employee surveillance activities?

comments.content: Basicaly nothing but surveiliance without employee notification and even better without having formal agreement might be often against low. And for sure might be considerend as immortal. CE Council seems to put big attention on such things. Of course question might be leading to wrong answers depending on how you feal and see the morality and low

choices.B: Employers use informal verbal communication channels to explain employee monitoring activities to employees.
choices.A: Employers promote monitoring activities of employees as long as the employees demonstrate trustworthiness.
choices.C: Employers use network surveillance to monitor employee email traffic, network access, and to record employee keystrokes.
choices.D: Employers provide employees written statements that clearly discuss the boundaries of monitoring activities and consequences.

questions.question_text: An ethical hacker for a large security research firm performs penetration tests, vulnerability tests, and risk assessments. A friend recently started a company and asks the hacker to perform a penetration test and vulnerability assessment of the new company as a favor. What should the hacker's next step be before starting work on this job?

choices.D: Use social engineering techniques on the friend's employees to help identify areas that may be susceptible to attack.
choices.A: Start by foot printing the network and mapping out a plan of attack.
choices.B: Ask the employer for authorization to perform the work outside the company.
choices.C: Begin the reconnaissance phase with passive information gathering and then move into active information gathering.

discussion.content: Keyword: 'Before starting work on this job'

comments.content: They're talking about the company he currently works for, not the friends company

discussion.content: Wrong, the friend is the owner, and he asked him to do the test

choices.D: Notify the vendor of the bug and do not disclose it until the vendor gets a chance to issue a fix.
choices.C: Find an underground bulletin board and attempt to sell the bug to the highest bidder.
choices.B: Create a document that will crash the computer when opened and send it to friends.
choices.A: Ignore the problem completely and let someone else deal with it.

questions.question_text: A computer technician is using a new version of a word processing software package when it is discovered that a special sequence of characters causes the entire computer to crash. The technician researches the bug and discovers that no one else experienced the problem. What is the appropriate next step?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The vendor should be notified of the bug so they can fix it

questions.answer_description:
The OSI layer 2 is where packet sniffers collect their data.
References: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame
questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

choices.C: Sniffers operate on both Layer 2 & Layer 3 of the OSI model.
choices.B: Sniffers operate on Layer 3 of the OSI model
choices.A: Sniffers operate on Layer 2 of the OSI model
choices.D: Sniffers operate on the Layer 1 of the OSI model.

discussion.content:
Sniffers operate at the data link layer of the OSI model, which means they do not have to play by the same rules as the applications and services that reside further up the stack. Sniffers can capture everything on the wire and record it for later review. They allow userâ€™s to see all of the data contained in the packet. While sniffers are still a powerful tool in the hands of an attacker, they have lost some of their mystical status as many more people are using encryption.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/protocol-analyzer11

Answer is C
Sniffers operate at Layers 2 and 3 of the OSI model. Layer 2 provides for physical addressing and framing (MAC addresses, Ethernet frames, and so on) and Layer 3 handles the packets and payloads (IP addressing and such).
sniffer operate on layer 2 and 3 of the OSI model, true is C

Selected Answer: A
tcpdump is passive.

comments.content: Yes, but this method is Active since you are interecting with the target system

discussion.content:
You might aswell fingerprint the target OS by using ping, and watching the TTL it displays.
If the TTL is 64: The target is a Linux Host
If the TTL is 128: The target is a Windows Host

questions.question_text: Which of the following tools can be used for passive OS fingerprinting?
questions.answer_description:
The passive operating system fingerprinting is a feature built into both the pf and tcpdump tools.
References: http://geek00l.blogspot.se/2007/04/tcpdump-privilege-dropping-passive-os.html
